logicalComponents
Class Controller.SerialIO

java.lang.Object
  logicalComponents.Controller.SerialIO
Enclosing class:
Controller
public class Controller.SerialIO
extends java.lang.Object

This class is what is used for receiving notifications from the serial port for incoming data, and also manages output to the serial port based on the state of certain flags. The details of this will be described in the serialEvent method. The information for each of the three flags are found below as well.

Author:
dmac

Field Detail

BREAK

public final int BREAK
The value that is used to interpret a break character with the development board. This value should not be changed unless it is changed on the development board as well.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

RESUME

public final int RESUME
The value that is used to interpret a continue character with the development board. This value should not be changed unless it is changed on the development board as well.

Method Detail

serialEvent

public void serialEvent(SerialPortEvent e)

This method handles receiving data from the serial port and determining what to do based on the status of the three flags.

Essentially the process is as follows:

  • An event is raised indicating that there is data in the input buffer of the serial port
  • The buffer is flushed and the values are stored in a local variable
  • the number of bytes that were received are added to the total of numIncomingBytes
  • the isSending flag is evaluated. If the flag is cleared, then the method returns at this point.
  • if the isSending flag is set, then we iterate through the array containing each byte that was in the input buffer and do the following:
    • if the sendingGesture flag is set, then send the next value in currentGesture
    • if the recordPlayback flag is set, then send the next value in currentRecording, increment ioIndex and continue to the next value in the buffer
    • otherwise the task is to record the movement from the glove. So the value is stored in currentInput at the index specified by ioIndex
    • set that value in the Hand class, so as to compute the position of the joint
    • write that position out to the serial port
    • update the ioIndex and continue to the next byte in the buffer
